articles.headline: Treasury Hails Milestone in Home Loan Modifications
articles.snippet: Half a million troubled homeowners have seen their loan payments lowered under an Obama administration program.
articles.abstract: Half a million troubled homeowners have seen their loan payments lowered under an Obama administration program.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, troubled homeowners seeking to lower their mortgage payments under a federal plan have complained about bureaucratic bungling, ceaseless frustration and confusion. On Thursday, the Obama administration declared that the $75 billion program is finally providing broad relief after it pressured mortgage companies to move faster to modify more loans.

articles.headline: F.H.A. Problems Raising Concern of Policy Makers
articles.snippet: A year after Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac teetered, industry executives and policy makers are worrying that the Federal Housing Administration could be the next housing domino.
articles.abstract: A year after Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac teetered, industry executives and policy makers are worrying that the Federal Housing Administration could be the next housing domino.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac teetered, industry executives and Washington policy makers are worrying that another government mortgage giant could be the next housing domino.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Louise Story

articles.headline: House Votes to Expand Hate Crimes Definition
articles.snippet: The 281-146 vote will expand the definition of violent federal hate crimes to cover those committed because of a victim’s gender and sexual orientation.
articles.abstract: The 281-146 vote will expand the definition of violent federal hate crimes to cover those committed because of a victim’s gender and sexual orientation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The House voted Thursday to expand the definition of violent federal hate crimes to those committed because of a victim’s sexual orientation, a step that would extend new protection to lesbian, gay and transgender people.

articles.headline: Leaving Iraq Is a Feat That Requires an Army
articles.snippet: The colossal effort to remove 20,000 American soldiers has been further complicated by insurgent attacks.
articles.abstract: The colossal effort to remove 20,000 American soldiers has been further complicated by insurgent attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOINT BASE BALAD, Iraq  There is no more visible sign that America is putting the Iraq war behind it than the colossal operation to get its stuff out: 20,000 soldiers, nearly a sixth of the force here, assigned to a logistical effort aimed at dismantling some 300 bases and shipping out 1.5 million pieces of equipment, from tanks to coffee makers.

articles.headline: Fed Is Split Over Timing of Rate Rise
articles.snippet: The arguments go beyond the split between “hawks” who worry that easy money will stoke inflation and “doves” who contend that unemployment is the top problem.
articles.abstract: The arguments go beyond the split between “hawks” who worry that easy money will stoke inflation and “doves” who contend that unemployment is the top problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Fissures are developing among policy makers at the Federal Reserve as they debate how and when to start raising the benchmark interest rate from its current level just above zero.

articles.headline: When Law Obscures the Facts
articles.snippet: A 1995 law designed to prevent frivolous lawsuits is preventing the details of the auction-rate securities debacle from emerging.
articles.abstract: A 1995 law designed to prevent frivolous lawsuits is preventing the details of the auction-rate securities debacle from emerging.
articles.lead_paragraph: The collapse of the auction-rate securities market is a largely forgotten part of the financial crisis, a disaster that was soon overwhelmed by bigger ones  except for the investors who were caught up in it.

articles.headline: Flying Into Headwinds
articles.snippet: The flush times in military spending are coming to an end, and Boeing, which has sharply expanded its defense business in recent years, could be the biggest loser.
articles.abstract: The flush times in military spending are coming to an end, and Boeing, which has sharply expanded its defense business in recent years, could be the biggest loser.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As Senator John McCain argued recently in a floor debate to strip $2.5 billion worth of cargo planes from a military spending bill, he complained that members of Congress could not “walk through these hallways without bumping into a lobbyist from Boeing.”

articles.headline: Hedge Firm Says Chief Will Retire
articles.snippet: James H. Simons told investors he plans to step down from day-to-day management of Renaissance Technologies, the firm he founded over 30 years ago.
articles.abstract: James H. Simons told investors he plans to step down from day-to-day management of Renaissance Technologies, the firm he founded over 30 years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: James H. Simons, one of the most respected money managers in the hedge fund industry, told investors Thursday he planned to step down from day-to-day management of Renaissance Technologies, the firm he founded over 30 years ago.

articles.headline: Surprise Nobel for Obama Stirs Praise and Doubts
articles.snippet: The Nobel Peace Prize, which President Obama described as a “call to action,” was an extraordinary recognition for so early in a presidential term and a potential political liability at home.
articles.abstract: The Nobel Peace Prize, which President Obama described as a “call to action,” was an extraordinary recognition for so early in a presidential term and a potential political liability at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  The choice of Barack Obama on Friday as the recipient of the 2009 Nobel Peace Prize, less than nine months into his eventful presidency, was an unexpected honor that elicited praise and puzzlement around the globe.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Citigroup Sheds Energy Unit and Its $100 Million Trader
articles.snippet: With the sale of the energy-trading unit to Occidental, Citigroup could potentially avoid controversy over the compensation of Andrew J. Hall, who ran the firm.
articles.abstract: With the sale of the energy-trading unit to Occidental, Citigroup could potentially avoid controversy over the compensation of Andrew J. Hall, who ran the firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup is letting go of its $100 million man, Andrew J. Hall, and the lucrative energy trading business he ran, after Washington’s special compensation master threatened a public showdown over his nine-figure bonus.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Jack Healy
